Reffing Hell

16/02/2015

After a series of recent high-profile blunders in football, Jamie Summers takes a look at the role of the referees in the game, from George Waring to Jose Mourinho.

Image by

By undefined undefined

[caption id="attachment_119499" align="aligncenter" width="620"] Middle-aged blokes wearing relatively tight black clothing that happens to be a size or two too small have been in the news recently. No, I'm not talking about something that should've been banned in the government's new porn regulations, but referees. I've no doubt that some of it has been because it's a slow news day, and TV journos caked in stage makeup need to fill the hours somehow. But in the main, referees have been making headlines because they've made some pretty shocking decisions recently. This got me thinking: are referees just bad, or are they scapegoats for other people's underperformance? Before I get into this, I'd like to say - to the chap with the Keegan-esque barnet who usually referees Constantine Firsts matches; I don't know your name, but even though we may give you a bit of stick from time to time on the touchline, you do a cracking job. It seems to me that there's two very valid sides to this debate - both of which I think are wrong, as I'll try to explain. It's well known in football circles that the referee is a wanker. It doesn't matter who the man (or, since a few years ago, woman) in the middle of the park is or what they do, they can't win. Managers, players and pundits seem to relish in pointing out every time they drop the ball (excuse the quite-possibly-intentional pun). It's easy for the likes of Alan Shearer and Robbie Savage to sit in a TV studio, analysing refereeing decisions in slow motion from 765 different angles; but referees doesn't have that benefit. They have one chance to see a tackle in real time, and often not always from a particularly good angle. Throw in an emotive, highly-charged atmosphere, and it's easy to make mistakes. The problem became so acute a few years ago that the FA introduced the 'Respect' campaign, encouraging everyone to pay referees the respect they deserve. It's easy to see why; sometimes, fans just get it wrong themselves. Over Christmas, I went to watch Stockport County play Colwyn Bay at home. Stockport, with an excellent home record, were expected to win, but could only manage a draw. Colwyn Bay took the lead in acrimonious circumstances. From where I was sitting, I was sure there was a foul in the build-up to the goal. So did a few thousand others - including the manager, who let his opinions be known after the match; cue abuse hurled towards the ref. Once I got home and watched the highlights, there was no foul. Our left-back got done for pace and it was just a terrible bit of defending. The referee was right after all. Oops. Officials even get a hard time at York. At the start of this academic year, after two years of watching distinctly average College Football for this paper, three veterans of the York media scene, of which I was one, decided to get involved with the management of new kids on the block, Constantine AFC. In one match, Halifax's George 'Crouchy' Waring was refereeing a Seconds game. At one stage, there was a tough decision to make - but in hindsight, the trio of myself, Tom Fennelly and Isaac Lister (or Fenn-Goran Eriksson and Roy Podgson as they are colloquially known - I won't reveal my nickname for watershed reasons) screaming "BACKPASS!" in unison probably didn't help. Sorry Crouchy. Nationally, the numbers taking refereeing courses is in alarming decline. It's here where the Respect campaign has failed. Yes, referees have a tough job; but if all that people see is poor decisions, then how can they be expected to hold any kind of respect for the officials? This is the crucial point - referees are human, and making the occasional mistake is par for the course. But sometimes, they do just make some terrible decisions that can cost a team the game. Nowadays, lose three or four matches and managers can get the sack - so of course they're going to become angry and say things in haste, because managers are human too. This isn't some kind of manager love-in. Sometimes, they go over-the-top. Taggart got away with it for 20-odd years at Manchester United, and there's no doubt that referees were intimidated when taking big decisions against them; 'Fergie time' was no mistake. It seems that the apprentice, Jose Mourinho, has learned the tricks well, complaining of a 'campaign' against his players. Perhaps Jose would do well to remember that if his players didn't drop like a sack of shit every time another player made contact in the area, they might not have earned themselves the (possibly unfair) reputation of being cheats. At the same time, when managers do have valid reasons to feel angry and dare to make a comment about it in the heat of the moment, the FA throws the book at them with the one-size-fits-all charge of 'bringing the game into disrepute.' Frankly, it's bollocks; as usual, they're missing the point. Recently, the former referees' chief Keith Hackett, felt compelled to complain that refereeing standards are slipping. In response his successor, Mike Riley, suggested that somewhere in the region of 92% of refereeing decisions are correct - as though that sort of thing matters when your team has just been incorrectly denied a last-minute penalty. What Riley was trying to point out is that referees are usually right, but when they do get decisions wrong, it gets blown out of proportion. That's the nature of the media; news is about a deviation from the norm. It doesn't get reported when trains run on time, because they're meant to. The same applies to referees getting decisions right. 'Referee does job' doesn't make for a very good headline. Ultimately, it boils down to this: referees don't want to make mistakes. They don't ever step out onto the field and intentionally think "I'm going to have a terrible game today." Likewise managers (or at least most of them) don't want to be moaning about it afterwards. Surely, the only way to improve refereeing again is to work together. The media need to stop being sensationalist, managers and players need to exercise a bit of common decency in realising that mistakes can happen, and the authorities need to realise that referees aren't infallible. Only when there's a relationship based on respectful understanding, standards will improve again, more people will take up refereeing, and everyone will be happy. Then we can leave it to the terraces to decide whether the referee really is a wanker after all.
